element_texts.text: Completed

At sister Conants?
Warwick Sept 10th 1853
My Dear Son, I wrote to you last week but think I'll write again because I do want answer from you directly so that I can know whether you are coming + if you are coming--when so as to make my calculations accordingly--If you don't want to come, or think it not expedient to come--you need not consider it necessary for you to, on my account for I can go back alone without any difficulty or danger I think.--Tho' it might be pleasanter to have company.
If any thing should prevent your coming and I do not hear from you before that time I think I shall start for home about the 25 of this month You need not feel that it is any great affair or needs any great preparation--you can come from Bangor here in 24 hours at the cost of about 4, or 4,50 + you won't want to stay more than a week you can see all the folks you'll want to see--as long as you'll want to see them--I have been down on the Brook one day which is all I care about it is so long since I've seen 'em much + I feel so unacquainted that I don't care to stay any where except with sisters
When I came I left the Greenfield rout? at Grants and got into the Brattleborough Cars + came on to Northfield and Mr. Parsons  brought me out here You can do the same or stop at Wendall which is about as near here if I could know just when you'd come I guess I could get Mariah to go down there after you
Completed

now do be sure to write by the very next mail and let me know your calculations and all about it Conchide? what, and when, and how you'll do and let me know + set about it immediately.
I don't think you'll want to stay more than a week so that you need not be gone more than 10 days or so from home. Your things at home won't get very much out of fix in that time if you can't leave them just as you would wish.
Perhaps you have written + I may receive a letter from you before you get this but if you have written I want you should write again and by the very next mail. Good bye.
A.M. Metcalf
54

Completed

Warwick Sept 19th 1853
My Dear Children,
I receiv'd your letter today I feel very sorry you cannot conveniently come--But cheifly on your own account--I don't know as it would be consistent for you to leave home if it was I think you would enjoy it and that it would do you good--I think I can go home alone without any difficulty and I rather think that I shall start for home in about ten days from now
I am now at the good old family mansion where I was born + brought up + O how familiar and dear every spot seems to me the great rock? the garden the Orchard the great walnut trees + every foot of ground where my little bare feet us'd to run I suppose there is no better pasture land about + yet it appears to me that one half of the surface of the great east pasture here is bare rock + yet this Farm was pric'd at 1930!! + the mountain lot 320! about 8, an acre for the mountain pasture!!
Maria + her mother live here alone except she hires a man a part of the time. She buys + sells cattle + horses etc. + carries on all her farming business with as much judgement + discretion as a man as far as I can see She bought her a Horse not long since + this morning she sold 3 cattle Sister Hannah tho' she's a little delicate old feeble looking woman does most of the house work making butter etc. and she braided hats enough last year to come to 30 dollars!!
Completed

It beats  all how painfully economical & industrious people are here.  Everything looks just about exactly as it did forty years ago except that the rich have grown richer & the poor have disappeared.  The large fish have cut up the small ones - Bet you can't think how lonely it seems at the house without Brother Joseph.  I can't be content to stay here many day.  I have concluded not to go to Dunbarton & don't think I shall go to Royalston so it is possible that I may be at home at Bangor by about the first of Oct.  If it is convenient shall go to Milo in a week or two after.  Tell Charlie I am very glad indeed that he has learn'd all that hymn hope he will say it over often so as not to forget & I suppose Jane will help him think of it & try to learn him all she can.  I hope & expect that she has become a good industrious patient girl and is a great comfort to you all - I thought before I come away that she was trying to do well & we know that she can if she tries be a very capable, good girl.
May God be with you, & bless you and guide you in all your ways from your affectionate Mother.
I intended to send this by the last mail but we have had a very rainy time for several days, & Maria had nobody to send.  I don't know but what if I could know that you could conveniently come in a fortnight from now I should wait - but tis so uncertain - I think I had better be getting home and after I get home & you get your harvestry done you had better take a trip somewhere perhaps to N.York - or you can come here if I am gone home & you'll find plenty of peaches & chestnuts.
Completed

Cedar Grove Milo Feb 11th 1854
My Dear Son, I return here yesterday Eliot came up with me and has gone back this afternoon -- received letters from Isaac and Antoinette last tuesday I was very much amus'd at the account of Sam'l's arrival at there I hope he will enjoy himself & do well & you likewise. Sam'l must have had rather a hard time getting out there I want very much to hear more about him how he left his family & etc. Sister Conant wrote me that your uncle Conant had made his Will given Sam'l 50 dollars and  Hervey all the rest it is too bad I think but he is of one mind I really think that he means to do just right & thinks he does in so doing His father gave him all after fixing of 3 dughters & himself & wife were sick a great while so that all was very little, & he of course thought he must do as his father did Why don't you write more particularly about
(left margin) have you or has he any idea that you should ever like that part of the country for a permanent residence
(upper margin) Tell Sam'l Conant I should be very glad if he would write to me and tell how he likes there & what he thinks of Isaac & you and all the suckers out there He looks rather deep into things I should value his opinion & judgement in many things very highly
Completed

what you are doing how you like your work & how you like the country how Sam's like & what he is doing - I am a little afraid you don't like as well as you expected tell me about it & whether Sam'l is disappointed.  I want to know all about how you feel-what you think & whether you are glad you went there.  Eliab did not feel willing I should come up in the stage thought I could come more comfortably with him but it cost him some for he broke his sleigh thills which with his house hire would be six or seven dollars I suppose - Mr R R Harkin, is almost gone in consumption is not expected to live many days I fear that they are going to be rather hard with Eliab  he thinks they ought to give him more because he has had all the work to do as Mr H has been so sick all the time.  They don't seem inclin’d to but perhaps they'll do what is right - bye and bye.  He has met with quite a loss again on the Brig Susan Duncan.  Percie has had another attack of the croup not so bad as before the little fellow has been wrong'd by being kept in a warm room so continually - has never been suffer'd to snuff the out door air half as much as he ought
Completed

I suppose Allina keeps you "posted up" in regard to things about home - I found Jessie pretty sick but evidently getting better weak feverish & fretful, but has considerable appetite.  He coughs some yet but I think he will be pretty smart in a few days - Charlie is pretty well look more healthy and is more fleshy than when I went away.  Little Mary has some cold & is cutting teeth.  She is too spunky to be sick - but she is on the whole rather pleasanter than she was last fall.  Uncle Mark has gone as suppose you know & James does the chores at the barn probably they are not done just as you would do but I guess he is pretty faithful.  We have had a long spell of very cold weather - Mercury down to 30 below zero some days - which has made it hard for James, & the ((unclear)) at the barn too suppose our ham is abominably cold - The school has but two week more to keep - them James can get along well enough if his folks will let him play but Mr. Rider will think he can earn considerable at home - He is more manly & steady than he was a year or two ago but he is a boy yet.
Completed

Sabbath eve I have been up to Mr Sargents today he & his wife were both in one bed sick.  He is very sick with lung fever, she has neuralgia in her head, Mrs. Dales was there & some other neighbours came in, & got up another bed & mov'd the cookstove out into the kitchen & put our open stove, that you left in ((unclear)) closet, up in their room, & Mrs Dolen is going to stay and take care of them - it has been rather sickly about here some cases of scarlet fever in the first part of winter - & measles at the village.  Colds & coughs in abundance all about.  Tis a cold, hard, rough, country here, - I suspect that James feels a little anxiety about whether he is to have pay & how much, I've been thinking &would wish to his Father & Mother & see what they think would be right - I don't see but we must keep him if we can can at whatever price - for it is next to impossible to get a man or boy to do anything -  it is rather hard times for poor folks I suppose, every think is so high corn 1,30 oats, 75' flour 11, or 12,00 - wood in Bangor 5, to 6,5'0 - we are burning here green white birch - however the school will soon be done and the weather will be warmer & we will all get along nicely - no not nicely, but comfortably, tolerably can we, or had me better try to do anything about getting the house paintd, paper'd before Mr DeWitt comes - Shall you be home soon enough to do it they have not said when they should come but suppose in May or first June - a great deal of love to Isaac & Antoinette & the Dear little D Mayo.  Can you make it worth while for you to stay during the spring if I probably the work can be done some way if it is best write, write
Completed

Cedar Grove, Milo, March 19th 1864

Allena is writing to Samul just say a word to tell you we are well and liking to "spring out" nicely.  Sam'l says the snow was all of 5'feet deep in the roads till 2 days of warm weather in the last week settled it some - but yesterday it snow'd & blow'd again today the roads are blocked up with hard drifts.
Charlie is learning to read some but it requires all the coaxing strategies I can muster to keep up our interest in it somedays he seems very much engag'd & then again it is hard work - He can, read off favourably well in two syllables and in reading words of 3 or 4 letters.
He waits up on the table when there is no other man here with considerable grace & dignity - took it up of his own hand - & insist upon the privilege  with some pertinancy ever since Janie went away he has split up his kindling wood at night & got up & built the fire - with being tod.
Those warm days he was marching round on the snowdrifts on a ((unclear)) of wooden snow ((unclear)) that summer & he rigg'd up - Joseph got well very quick after he was sick.  He eats very hearty & his cheeks really stick out he is so fat now.  Little Mary does not talk but can make herself understood, is very old for her age, sits up in her dinner chair & feeds herself at table.
Completed

you say you & others are building a house who is your master work man or don't you have any in two or three of your last letters you have not mention'd S Conart.  I am very much interesd to know all about what kind of a man he is & how he is preparing.
What do you read or don't you have time to read much of anything - on the whole are you getting to be a more perfect man for going out there of course you are gaining some knowledge whether it is the most useful knowledge for you is another question.  However that may be I trust you are doing some good to yourself & others.  May Furber has married last month to a widow lady of M Ford 45 years old - ((unclear)), they suppose are to be soon - Mr. Sargent is getting better slowly don't sit up much yet - we are all in good health now.  
Allina says she has felt healthier & stronger than usual this winter - I tell her that the care & culmination that falls  up on her in your absence has it's advantages.

 tell her that the care & culmination that falls gives her fortitude perhaps, she is very chicken headed sometimes & mole hills seem like mountains.
The snow hides the fences all up the road - the nursery has been all out of sight for many weeks - How have you made out for clothes for yourself to provide yourself with things & decent & comfortable you ought to have carried more shirts & drawers ought not to get much mending done by Nettie.  Suppose she has enough to do.  Don't be so anxious to save money as to cheat yourself in any way of a generous living a man is estimated very much by the dress he wears you are very apt to not dress well enough.
I shall be lonely more this long spring, write to me often.  Ask Isaac & Nettie to likewise - Lucy wants very much & should be there next month which she ((unclear)) -  but tis bad going back & forth so often.
Completed

Friday june 9th, 1854
My Dear Son  Albina just had a letter from you dated 21st of May  Charlie went down to the P.O. after it 2 days ago I had a letter from Anna they expect to be in Boston on the fourth of july - not to be here before the second week in july probably Isaac will tell you all about us here, you cannot think or imagine how surprised & glad I was to see him at Brownville & I feel troubled too that he has such luck & has to be so delay when he was so pressed for time I feel very grateful to him - We had a letter from Lucy Wednesday saying that she & Antoinette & Sam'l & the two babies & the woman to take care of them, were coming first of next week
We have sent to S. & I. for flour, Molasses, tea, Coffee, Sugar, [unclear] fixings for the room, in fine for whatever they think we need. The water has been up twice over the intervale as Isaac will tell you  So that Walter is rather late about the farming - and yesterday we had another smart rain the ground where the corn has just been planted is some of it under water  it came up so as to stop them before they got it quit all plants today 
The trees & the grass have grown very rapidly considerable grass was winter killed but where it is not it looks finely the [?] north of the house looks beautifully - the carrots, beets, turnips not sow'd yet - it has been so wet & Walter is not very rugged & there is many chores to do you know, when I get home from Brownsville I advised to hire some help and we have made out to get George Hodgham half a month for 5 dollars - there will be work on the road you know I have just ask'd him if he should like to stay here all summer if you want him, he said he would
Written on top of third line from the bottom
Sheep not washed or sheered yet
Completed

Walter wants you should come home before staying as--(tho he is a smart hand to mow they say if he is not his side is lame & he can't pitch hay or mow much I suppose-- I suppose you are earning more wages than the hire of a good smart man would be here (if one could be obtain'd)--perhaps it could be done or let out the hay but you know the Barn needs fixing and it will not secure the hay--& no one can do your work to just as good advantage as you can yourself--Mo' Walter seems interested & careful about everything as if it was his own & gets along nicely & if he can't do too much in a day it seems so he can better than the hir'd men we have usually had [seems more like one of our folks]

I feel Isaac will work too hard do warn him & charge him to be careful of his health he looks very different from what he [said] to --- and do be careful of yourself and come away before you get the "shakes"

It is very very hard for Charlie to learn to read I get quite discourag'd sometimes & he does quit he has not tried much this 3 or 4 weeks past [we haven't tried to have him read at all] he had rather do any thing rather than look in a book--I went out in the back room last night & he was sitting alone on the floor by the stove looking very sad I told him he'd better go to bed-- he said he did not want to grow any bigger I asked him why? He answered because he did not learn he did not want to grow bigger he could learn but he is going to school next week perhaps he'll take a new start then
I shall direct this to Isaac as perhaps it might not get there till you have started for home to do your staying you'll get here before Anna comes
June 10th
If you do come home
Completed

Written upside down on the top:
My health is good I was unwell a few days

Bangor Sept. 3rd /54
Dear Albina
I expected we should get a letter from you Wednesday  I do think a good deal about home & want to know all how you are getting along - How is Walters health now? Does George stay there all the time? - has Jane gone to Brownville & Sally come back? - Are you likely to have any harvesting to do? in some places the Corn potatos' (?) &c. are all entirely cut off & the partners so wholly dries up that they have to feed cattle at their barns so they say  I hope it is not to bad on the intervale - If Charles stays till towards spring you will need to get a cookstove before he comes home & take care & get up plenty of wood early in the season.
Does Walter think any of taking the farm next year if C. wants to let it - Charles wrote to Eliab that he thought it might be best not to sell the wood but pack it away & keep it till another year unless the price comes up
Lucy says you had better come here soon - before cold weather & that Charlie had better come as soon as E. & wife move away which will be in a few weeks if she gets along as smart as she has done they have hired a house & are now paying rent for it will probably move by the first part of Oct. - when Charlie comes you had perhaps send what aprons & other clothes that he has - but if he is to have any new ones have'em made here Send the old cloak that was Janes & we can make it - his old boots would do to wear at home but not to mill have perhaps you can fix'em up & save'em for Josie
Written upside down:
Much obliged for your letter rec'd last night 
Do write often love to all the folks good bye
Completed

Friday Sept 22nd
Dear Albina  I feel so anxious about Mary and you that I can think of nothing else so I'm begin to write before you get home even - I seem as if I couldn't wait till tomorrow night before hearing from you I am afraid you will get sick carrying Mary so far in your arms
I got so tir'd and nervous yesterday that I even had a cry myself after I went to bed I had not been asleep when I went into your chamber - most two o clock  I got to thinking about Mary being sick & Charles gone &c &c &c &c
But I have been abed - had a good nap, & all looks bright & hopeful - tho' I feel anxious & shall till I hear   am sorry you didn't take the flannel or blanket to put round her feet
Sat evening 10 oclock have just got your bit of letter  I am so glad to hear that you got home well - I do feel as if Mary is going to be well right off  but must wait all the time Tuesday before we can know whether she is sick or not - I had [unclear] upon your having a good visit here but I hope you'll have a better one next time you come - Percie does seem to be getting better but it is very slow.l he is very nervous & fretful  very hungry but we fear to let him eat much
Up the left side then across the top:
My [unclear] expected to send them tuesday but got disappointed had letters from Charles & Isaac yesterday Charles [unclear] of coming home in Nov. or Dec. I am afraid he will be sick in conveyance but he has been so tried with our letters that I hope he wont have occasion [?] to alter his mind again
Completed

late Tuesday evening I have just got your letter 7 Charles's  am very glad to hear that Mary is better hope she'll be really well by the time you get this - You tell of giving her charcoal I should think it might be good a very little of it if you could get it fine enough but I don't see how you can with any means you have there it ought to be as fine as possible or it might do injury
The Dr was in today he thinks Percie is getting well  Ellen has got a very bad cold has not been able to do any thing since Sunday morning has been taking an emetic I guess she'll be better tomorrow - Eliab started for Boston yesterday we expect him back Saturday & Hattie [unclear] with week I guess - Better send Charlie by the first of the week after perhaps
So Charles has determined on coming right home it seems - perhaps it may be all for the best - but I think it very probable that he will be regreting (sic) it all winter - If he gets through the winter without being sick I am sure I shall be glad to have him at home  but I think we have not much reason to think he will - but let us hope & trust that all will be well
love to Walter & Sally and all the folks
from your affectionate mother
I don't see why you wont all live there this winter if C does come home each family by yourselves  [unclear] thousands of families live more crowded than that would be i.e. if they want to
Completed

Bangor - Thursday Oct 12th/15th

My Dear Daughter
Mr Rider has just gone from here to Dr ((unclear)) to have his face operated upon.   We can't but feel very much for him.  Almeda feels very bad tho' they both feel very glad he came.  Dr Mc ((unclear)) a short time since perform'd a similar operation, only worse.  I guess he understand  it thoroughly he said it would take no more than 2 or 3 minutes to cut it out, & get it all done up.
Why didn't you send Charlie - I ask'd L what I should say to you about his coming Sam'l said tell her we've been expecting him every mail & all disappoint that he did not come & if you were writing he should come send him right along.  I expect his habits have been such in regard to doing pretty much as he have a mind to that he would require some carer and attention, but I think it would be a real benefit to him to be here a while - I don't think that his Father will be home till December.  We had a letter from Isaac yesterday dated Oct 10th in which he say, that he is expecting to get through there by the 1st of Dec. If so I thought it most likely they would come home together.

 If you send Charlie the sooner he comes the better you need not to fix him send him just as he is.  I can see about that after he gets here -----Send him right along Saturday if you can, if not Tuesday.  Perrie is getting along nicely has gain'd most 2 pounds but him take comforter & mittens for it will be cold & he'll want to be out a good deal.  Please send my old shawl.
Completed

Dear Allina
I have just received your letter with Charles - Please inform me whether you got my two last letters one sent with Almeda, which she send to Walker and one from me & Lucy sent by Mr.Rider, it was tied up with a bundle together with a bunch of 20 envelopes also 2 or 3 other bundles & put in your little red wooden pail & left probably at your Fathers - I conclude that by some unfortunate mistake you have not got them or you certainly have sent Charlies - but the time in part I suppose it is hardly worth while to have him come at all this winter now, certainly not unless he can come right off this neck - it seems really unfortunate and much to be regretted that he has not been here these 5 or 6 weeks while they would
Completed

have been glad to have him and would have walked over him with so much care and ((unclear)) to do him good & it certainly would have been a great benefit to him.  We have wondered and wondered why you did not send him - I have felt that instead of necessary great benefit - he has been all this fall very unfavourably situated - having his own head so much I am very much afraid that he is getting to be a great ignorant bad boy.  If he is not well instructed and gets any naughty habits it will be much harder learning the others to do right.  If by good fortune you should get this tomorrow and can send Charlie this week perhaps you had better send him - I really think it a great loss to him & to his parents that he has not been here this fall - I doubt whether they will want him in the winter.
Completed

I suppose Walter could not earn near so much on his farm besides paying his board as he will expect of Charles.  I should think he would prefer to stay.  I hope Charles will be home soon but I have all along thought that he would stay till they get done there which Isaac says will be in December he hopes by the first of the month.
I hope Walker has used the steers some & got them handy - Why did not they keep the oxen longer.  Did they not want them to plow & get wood.  Please write soon & say whether you get our letters.
I am staying with Ehabs wife while her sister is gone & Ehab is going to Boston tomorrow.  The baby grows muchly -  Bernie is growing strong and fat he walks all about the house.
Yours affectionate
Mother
Completed

Bangor Nov, 14th/15th

My Dear Daughter
I suppose you are busy now all day, making shirts & knitting stockings for Charles 3 or 4 weeks will soon pass away when we hope he will be at home.  I suppose he has written to you about the dreadful accident they have had there.  How shocking it must have been.  Nothing compar'd with many others R.R accidents but Isaacs coming so near being one of the victims and nothing so directly all about it affected me more than others that I have heard of where there were many more lives lost.  If you could send me some yarn I could knit some stockings for Charles as well as nat - Lucy & I both spoke of it & intended to write to you that she borrow'd a little girls coat to make Percies by & behold it was made just like many a little blue one a pretty large yoke & plaited down with a belt round and a large cape.  Little children from a year old to Charles age all wear large capes to their cloak, whatever the form of the cloak may be - I hope you have not alter'd many, for it is exactly in fashion & it would be a good deal of work to fix it over.
Completed

Percie?? has just got one more eye tooth thro' has got two now the others swelld a good deal.  Lucy is very miserable a few days past with the back ache.  Went a shopping and got too much tired.  She is so apt to do too much before she is aware of it that I don't know as she will ever get well.  Charlie is a very good boy has nothing to make him any other way -  Charlie has been scribbling on a piece of paper what he calls a letter but he thought you could not read it so I write it off just as he told me - He has learn'd the way down to his ((unclear)) Ehab has gone down there now of an errand.

  Charlie came of his own accord the other day & wanted to write a letter to ((unclear))  Mother helped him.  He was going to begin with Allina but Mother told him how this is exactly as he told it over. "Dear Mother, Uncle Samuel has got me some new books. I tee up the cow every day & feed her and clean out the barn.  How do you get along nowadays without me?  How does Joseph get along & how does Mary do?  Does she have spells now?  (meaning sick spells)  Percie has got blocks a whole lot, some with pictures in them and play with them."  What a fine rain and what a dear day after it - with love, Sister Lucy.
Completed

Jan 15th 1855
My Dear Children
We have a letter from Isaac dated 7th Jan. He and his expect to be here in two or 3 weeks - is stopping to visit her friends
I have forgotten every time to ask you Albina whether you have seen my black fur tippet I suppose I wore it home last winter but I have tryed & try'd (sic) to recollect about it but I cant remember anything when I had it last or where I put it - I did not think of it when I left home I wonder why I did not
Charlie's little collars never left here thru my carelessness & I intended to tell you that Saml had your Chickens & sold 'em at the store and gave Charlie credit for them. What are you & Charles reading nowadays, or dont you have time to read anything
Lucy you know got very much rundown last summer I thought she would [unclear] again as Revere got better & the cold weather came & she has some but she is not near as strong as she was a year ago cannot bear near as much fatigue or exposure & Revere tho' he grows fat & large does not seem to be quite well - He has never been "just right in his bowels since he was sick
What a blessing it is to enjoy good health are you & I thankful enough. Maria has had a very bad cold and her baby too - We had a letter from Anna last Saturday She is well & happy as ever every time she writes she talks about having company - Some half dozen folks, to stay several weeks or just had a party or some such thing
Completed

I wish you write more and often I want to know how you are all getting along do write more about the Children you say little M frets & whines - one thing that I wanted to do is try to make her think she is a good pleasant child - I imagine that she has a strong impression (perhaps too strong ever to be removed) that she is a naughty girl - If she has it will have a great tendency to make her so - She is a very affectionate child & I believe she may become mild and pleasant
It is needful for children to be in the habit of fretting & scolding at each other - I would reprove it more severely than the doing of any mischief - I think it has a bad effect on their whole life - it is so much better to take things easy - to be always thankful & happy
O if I could only do as well as I can say what an example I should be for others to follow but - Alas!! I write chiefly for the sake of getting letters from you dont disappointme it will do you good as well as me
Completed

Bangor Nov. 17 /55
My Dear Children,
If this reaches you in season i.e. before the Bundle is sent - I want you to send the pieces of my all wool Delaine dress I very carelessly forgot'em they are I think in the upper drawer of the new chest at the left hand end of the drawer - If not there look in the middle drawer - you may send also an old green velvet bag - which is also in the upper drawer - When I came away I did not think of my Cloak Sleeves at all - I usually have kept them pinned on to my Cloak - But they were not on the cloak when I got here - perhaps I have lost em no great matter if I did  If you see them there please lay them up - I do not want them sent
I am sorry I had to leave that chest & drawers so stir'd up & out of fix - but let them remain if I live to go home again I can fix'em then
I hope Mrs. S will send my little eye salve box as I shouldn't know just what to enquire for if I [unclear] to get more
Much love to you all from your Mother
I know I shall want the pieces of dress but I suppose is not worth while to send'em if you have already sent the other thing
Completed

My Dear Children
Here I am yet waiting for Isaac to get ready to go westward am as pleasantly & comfortably situated as any body need to be except that it seems as if it was not just where I ought to be
Isaac & Nettie are keeping house they have set the Father & Mother aside or rather they have set themselves aside & Isaac provides & Nettie directs all the household matters  She has very excellent help a tall dignified handsome well lived well inform'd kind hearted & pleasant agreeable in her manner, of a healthy & respectable family & with all good sense enough to know & observe the proprieties of her situation - how fortunate it is for Nettie that she can have such help while Isaac is gone
Completed

Isaac talks some of going round to Brattleborough on the way to call on Joseph Stevens & perhaps to Warwick - I was expecting to start next Monday but Isaac keeps pleasing - he is luying in provisions getting wood &c &c Says he has been married this some time & got quite a family of children & I have never made him a visit before &c. - would go I suppose if I insist upon it but it would be more convenient for him to stay a week or two longer on till it comes Sledding so that he can get his winters wood  I hardly see how it can be so but they [Mr. D] seem to have every convenience & luxury that one could expect if the Salary was 12 or 1500, instead of 400 - large cottage house well furnish'd tho' not in the newest while yet neat convenient & complete in every part (necessary [unclear] & completed)
Completed

a great many people have call'd to pay their compliments to Nettie & the twins - It is very pleasant place here - much more so than I expected I should think it must be delightful in the summer 
These lines are Xd out:
My Delaine dresses are both so worn already that I fear I shall need another for an after noon before I get to Elyria or have to put on my [unsure] 
The people about here as far as I can judge are rich live in great houses dress well &c but are probably like other farming places very industrious & economical
They have a prayer meeting every tuesday afternoon in the vestry a few steps from here - also one in the Pastors study the same evening prayers for their families & the church "family prayer meeting" a few good people have kept it up constantly for 30 years tho' sometimes no more than 2 or 3 attend Do write often - I have not written to Milo please send this if you are writing them
Completed

Dec. 13, 1855
Dear Sister Lucy
I this day send to you the December Number of Putnam's Magazine - The other numbers of the 6th Vol. are I believe with you; therefore I prefer to send this there also.
Please read this, and then if not too much trouble tie up the 6 Numbers of the 6th Vol. together, and lay them away to be found. It is possible that I may sometime visit Bangor again, and may get them. Do you hear from L.W.? 
Please write to us.
I expect Mother is homesick & she wont let me see what she has written.
I.S. & Nettie
Nettie says the twin infants are probably named
Willis Putnam & Wilder Stevens
Completed

Written across the top:
To Charles & Albina    1855
Dunbarton Dec 29th
My Dear Children
I thank you very much for your letters I was very glad indeed to hear from home I expected to have been gone from here long ago - but Isaac wanted very much to tary till we could have a few days of wedding -- & there has been no snow here till this week
The people here are very pleasant & genteel & very good - a good large cottage house very completely furnished -- the sitting room is 24 or 26 feet long & 16 wide with 4 windows warm'd by a stove like yours in the kitchen - it has a bed, large mirror & wash stand a good wide sofa (occupied chiefly by the two "tins" as Mayo calls 'em) a secretary & book case & a Seraphine on which Nettie plays sometimes
Written upside down:
I think I have got this sheet pretty full tho not well filled Much love Isaac
Completed

I wish you could see the dear little boys they have grown beautifully they hold up their little hands and look at 'em & laugh & crow they lay on the lounge by the hour at a time & hardly cry at all
Mr. S. [?] has 9 1/2 acres of land which he lets out at the halves has no manure except from one horse he says the clear benefit last year was 90 dollars - He does no work at all himself.
Isaac & Nettie are regularly keeping house he provide & she directs the household
The idea that the blessing of God maketh such & that those wealthy individuals or communities get along the best who do their duty seems plainly exemplified here - there are about 900 inhabitants in this town their yearly contribution to benevolent objects is 200, a
Completed

year besides supporting a minister The people are merely farmers no kind of manufacturing done in town There is not even a grist mill the land tho' good perhaps is certainly very rocky & hard to cultivate & yet the people appear not only well off, but rich
They have a contribution regularly every 2 months in support of six different benevolent societies an) in the vestry a few steps from here - besides which a few Devoted Christians have kept up a meeting one evening in the week in the Pastors Study constantly for over 30 years their custom is always to have 3 prayers one for theirselves and families, one for the Church and people of the town & one for all mankind
Completed

Mr. S. says each acre of his land is as good as 150, at interest is'nt it strange that land is so productive here when it is so rocky & hard - But the people work as Gilman Rider does I suppose & they have a real good market for every thing at Manchester & produce is very high - higher than at Bangor
It seems as if the Boys, Charlie & Josie ought to be in school but I am very glad they do not go as it is - But I hope you will both take pains to learn them at home & it is better not to be done all in set lessons but incidentally every hour & almost every minute may admit of some question ask'd on precept enforced if your own minds are not too much taken up with work & every thing - you can do a good deal in that way - but I constantly would not try to have Charlie understand what he reads at present - I think that is the reason that he has been so slow to get the sounds & the combination of [unclear] I want they should learn to kind & polite to each other & to every body
Mrs. Putnam is a most perfect patron of ladylike politeness & kind attention to every body it is a great thing for a parent to have every [unclear] look & action such as ought to be imitated by child
Completed

Bangor Jan. 20th /57
Dear Children,
Sam'l says you could not find my keys to open the Bureau Drawer I presume you'll find them in my old work basket in the closet in my room that is where I generally keep them  I don't believe Isaac cares much about those old books that S. brought down - But probably there are some papers in the drawer that he wants, & memorandum Book &c
Did S. say anything about matching yarn he told me some time ago that he would rather you would let him have stocking yarn than pay him money for those things as it was not so easy to get it at Minnesota but it was before he knew that Almeda had sent any  I have footed 3 pr & there is enough to knit 3 pairs & I suppose that will do but if you have any that you don't want to use this winter I guess you had better send it - that Almeda sent is very poor uneven & so slack twisted  As to the Secretary I should be glad on Sam'ls account to have you take it but it is a great heavy thing and
Completed

not as handsome as your Old Desk would be if it was mended & new trim'd - However if you know that you shall not move away perhaps you had better take it  But Samuel says you will go west - that you can be better off if you can disperse of your property there for half what it is worth to go, to say nothing about the benefit to the children  A letter came to S. from his father while he was gone & another since he came back  He writes that John has lately made quite a purchase of a share [10th] I believe of a new town just laid out - & with a [unclear] mill privelege  I dont know as I remember right but I believe he said he could sell it now & make $10,000.   Sam'l talks that he shall take Percie with him when he goes in the Spring  It makes me feel sad I and I suppose it would be hard for him to leave him & be so far from him - But it seems as if it would be better for P. to stay here a year or two  I know they cannot any of them love him or bear with him as we do( I don't know how he is going to get him there for he [unclear] his pants every day or two)
You have family enough, so that you would'nt want him there but it would be better for him to be there with me than to go among strangers
Completed

His Father cannot be with even if his business should be such that he could have him board at the same place he can't know but very little how he is [unclear]  The Child needs dicipline (sic) as well as tender affectionate care & love  Lucy was so anxious that he should be with me - Said there was no other way that she could think of that she could take any comfort in thinking of - I suppose Almeda wont be glad to have him with her - But I expect Sam'l will think he must have him with him (& wants to show him to his folks)  Sam'l starts today for Boston N.H. &c - He thinks that James will go west & that Almeda will & Eliab says he shall go west. That he shall stay in Bangor but a few year longer 
S. says I had better go out to Elyria when he goes that all my Children will be out that way in a few years - I do not know what I may conclude but I dont feel now as if I should go next Spring I have not been with Almeda much this long time I don't feel like leaving her now she is in trouble
If I do not go west & shall if I live expect to be at Milo Mary Ely is coming here before long & I guess Sam'l Ely will be here next summer too but I dont know with much love to you all from your Mother
Completed

Bangor Feb 21st /57
My Dear son
I write a few words just to ask what you say and think about having Percie at your house and Almeda's this coming summer - I thinnk S. is more than half inclin'd to let me keep him - I know that Albina has care enough & I dont know but she would feel it a burden anyway but if he should be there I would be there too to take care of him. Eliab would be very glad to have us both stay here, & on some accounts it would be pleasanter but on the whole I should prefer not to - The children at Elyria are urging me to go there with Percie & Sam'l would prefer that to any other way - But he is expecting to go in about 4 weeks from now - & considering Almeda's trials & that I have seen her so very little this long time - it seems as if I cant go away so far so soon again But I want to know what you & Albina & 'Almeda think
Completed

Now do please write to me & tell me what I had better do & write immediately - Are not you coming down here soon I wish you would i.e. if it is best & convenient for you - could nt (sic) you get James to hay there while you come down here - we are all in good health now Irving has been quite sick with Lung fever about a week but has got about well now- Mary Ely came here about a week ago will be here all summer - I suppose Sam'l Ely will come in the spring - This will be the Home for them all I guess
I'm sorry I did n't think to write a day or two sooner as I fear you wont get it for almost a week
love to all the folks  good bye A.M. Metcalf
24th  Eliab has got his cow & she is a noble looking animal gives 2 quarts more milk the morn [unclear] than the calf can take calf 10 days old - a nice looking one & a "heifer calf' too I wish you could have it E. is going to sell it he can have 2 or 3 dollars for it - the cow is large gives very good milk - 50,00 so not very high for it I guess I intended this should have gone Monday do write soon - very soon
Completed

Bangor August 19th
My Dear Daughter
I dont think of any thing very special to wish to write but yet feel inclin'd to scribble a little - chiefly because I want to hear from home perhaps - [unclear name] had letter from Isaac yesterday came in seven days from Mt Hankins he & Charles were then in good health but we see by the papers that the cholera is round about in all the western Cities - The season is to far advanced now that I dont feel so much fear of the boys having it as I did - Isaac didn't say a word about Charles's coming home - I want very much to hear what he says about coming home after getting our letters  It seems that they are suffering very much there with the draugth (sic) the grass all dried up & the corn all spoil'd for eight weeks, Isaac said they had had no rain at all
I want to hear whether it is as dry at Milo as here the trees are dying & the corn in the garden all drying up the grass looks as brown as in november - What do you do about corn for the pigs - I believe Eliab said the price of corn is 85 cents he says if you want any supplies send to them/ Furber & Metcalf) of course - They can use to advantage & want to, all they money they have and
Completed

a great deal more & suppose but expect to furnish what you need - Have you sold the wool? Is Charlie at the Village yet? - I wish he could be at Almeda's while James is with you
Maria is about quite smart yet - Percie is better but not at all well - his gums very much swollen & his bowels in a bad state - don't play about on the floor any - but is very patient & quiet - Sam'l & Eliab are full very full of business - I should be glad to have you get some yarn spin enough for one pr womens stockings about middling fine & send it when you do the next & if you can get some yarn ready for Charles some stockings, I can knit it for you If he needs them I dont know whether he does - I guess I had got enough knit for Charlile & I suppos'd those that he had an were to small would be enough for Josie 
Am much obliged to you for sending Charles letter will send it back I shall feel really worried about Sam'l [unclear] till I hear from him & his family I think he would be more likely to have the cholera because he is so nervous and afraid of it
We had a letter from Anna today she arriv'd home the Friday after leaving here all well - if you can get corn there just as cheap there it is just as well I suppose
Your affectionate A. M. M.
Completed

might be interested & learn what they need to know if it was only by asking & answering questions just a short time every evening & then read some in the Bible.
I think no parent can feel justified or expect the blessing of God if they do not read the Bible to their children & make them sit still & listen - but not too long at once
All lessons for little children should be short & made interesting if possible. I should like to be at home to [unclear] out and hear all the incidents & everything that was said & done out to Ducoign - & hear the multiplicity of plans and [unclear] for the future - And make some arrangement about property matters but I can't be in two places at once - I am very conveniently & comfortably situated here in regard to going to meeting & every thing - I cant do any body much good any where so it is not much matter where I am in that respect - unless it is to be where I should make the least trouble
If you both would only write often long particular letters  I want exceedingly to know all your doings & sayings (your thoughts) all your cogitations & plans for the future
The Hymn "Whene'er I take my walk abroad" beginning on the 222nd page of "Songs for the little ones - Charlie began to learn I want he should learn it all, the more he learns the easier he can learn, somebody must take pains with him in order to his learning I should think that Lucy repeated to him the 2 first verses of that hymn more than 50 times - But we
Completed

know that he can learn many other things he does learn easy enough so that he can get book knowledge - "If the tool is dull put to the more strength"
If you will recollect a conversation I had with you about 7 years ago on neglecting to cultivate the intellect and allowing the whole soul & mind to be absorb'd in the things of time & sense the mere animal you may see a reason why Charles has no love for a Book & let it induce you both to put forth great & [unclear] effort to counteract the tendency to, all animal & no Soul remembering that whatever good you accomplish with the eldest is more than half accomplish'd with the younger ones for the copy will be follow'd whether good or bad
I punish'd Charlie once while here with a rod for improper immodest behavior - I wish he could be induc'd to tell exactly about it - but tis better for him that he should not know that I mentioned it - He has fine & tender feelings - has the stuff in him as Lucy says to make a noble & excellent man if rightly train'd
It seems to me that if I were you I would make the training the minds of the Children the all important work whatever else is neglected that should not be [unclear] - manners too should be daily & hourly attended to
I have a keener sense of it from seeing so much that appears uncouth & really impudent in Charlie without his being conscious that it was in any way improper - I am aware that there are many obstacles to overcome but they can & must be surmounted
A.M.M.
